Job.JobTitle: Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522 position at Los Alamos Middle School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522 is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Los Alamos Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522 encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522 also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Coach Assistant Boys Basketball LAMS Posting 522 role at Los Alamos Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.CompanyDescription: Los Alamos Public Schools coaching jobs

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Volleyball Head Coach position at Carson High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Girls Volleyball Head Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Carson High School, the Girls Volleyball Head Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Girls Volleyball Head Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Girls Volleyball Head Coach at Carson High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The High School Girls Tennis Coach at Carson High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the High School Girls Tennis Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Carson High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The High School Girls Tennis Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The High School Girls Tennis Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Carson High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the High School Girls Tennis Coach role at Carson High School.

At its core, the Girls Volleyball Coach at Eagle Valley Middle School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Assistant Football Coach at Carson High School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Assistant Football Coach are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Carson High School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Assistant Football Coach recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Assistant Football Coach collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Assistant Football Coach maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Carson High School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobDescription:
The Coach 2025 role at Wappingers Central S.D. is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Coach 2025 is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Wappingers Central S.D. are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Coach 2025 listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Coach 2025 encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Coach 2025 follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Wappingers Central S.D., the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Coach 2025 at Wappingers Central S.D., a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

DISTINGUISHING FEATURES OF THE CLASS: Provides for the care, prevention and treatment of athletic injuries and/or improves physical fitness of athletes for participation in various sports programs. Under the general supervision of a licensed physician and the District Athletic Director, incumbents of this position are responsible for the care and prevention and treatment of athletic injuries involving student athletes. In accordance with Section 8532 of New York State Education Law the practice of the profession of athletic training is defined as the application of principles and methods of conditioning athletes, preventing and treating athletic injuries through the use of appropriate preventative and supportive devices, under the direction of a physician, recognizing and evaluating athletic injuries, administering first aid and emergency care, developing and implementing treatment and rehabilitation programs for athletic injuries under the direction of a physician and the planning and implementation of programs and services to help prevent athletic injuries. Incumbents are responsible for the record keeping of athletic injuries and treatments. Does related work as required.

The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach role at Davis Middle School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Davis Middle School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Davis Middle School, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Boys 8th Grade Lacrosse Coach at Davis Middle School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

The Head Varsity Girls Tennis Coach position at Jerome High School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Varsity Girls Tennis Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Jerome High School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Varsity Girls Tennis Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Varsity Girls Tennis Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Varsity Girls Tennis Coach role at Jerome High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Head JV Softball Coach role at Jerome High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head JV Softball Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head JV Softball Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Jerome High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head JV Softball Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head JV Softball Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head JV Softball Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Jerome High School.

Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Worthington Kilbourne High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Girls Head Coach - Lacrosse supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Worthington Kilbourne High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
Qualifications: Should possess a strong background as a wrestling coach.
Must hold or be willing to obtain the following certifications:
*Certification in CPR
*Training necessary to apply for a Pupil Activity Supervisor Permit ("Sports Injury Prevention" & "First Aid for Coaches", etc.)
*Apply for the Permit
*Complete the online training: "Concussion in Sports/What You Need to Know"
*Complete the online training: "Fundamentals of Coaching"
*Fraud Training
Please complete the online application at the Butler County Area Application Consortium, www.applitrack.com. If you have questions regarding the application, please contact the Hamilton City Schools Office of Human Resources at (513)887-5000. If you have questions concerning this position, you may contact Missy Harvey, Hamilton City Schools Director of Athletics at (513)887-4819.

The Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Girls Basketball Junior Varsity Coach role at Normandy High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobDescription:
The 50% Freshman Girls Basketball position at Normandy High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the 50% Freshman Girls Basketball prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Normandy High School, the 50% Freshman Girls Basketball works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The 50% Freshman Girls Basketball encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the 50% Freshman Girls Basketball at Normandy High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach role at Lincoln High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Lincoln High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Lincoln High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Lincoln High School.

The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach at Lincoln High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Lincoln High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Lincoln High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Assistant Football Coach at Lincoln High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. The Assistant Football Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Assistant Football Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Assistant Football Coach at Lincoln High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
New Hire Coaching Application: Job posting for coaches already hired into the district.
Employee shall remain free of any alcohol or non-prescribed controlled substance, use in the workplace throughout his/her employment with the District.
The Upper Arlington City School District Board of Education does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, including sexual orientation and transgender identity, disability, age, religion, military status, ancestry genetic information, or any other legally protected category, in its program and activities, including employment opportunities.

The incumbent will be required to follow the instructions and perform the duties required by the incumbent's supervisor and or appointing authority.

JOB SUMMARY This position is responsible for coaching and providing direction to student athletes so that they achieve a high level of skill as well as an appreciation for discipline, sportsmanship and teamwork in softball.
QUALIFICATIONS High School certification and previous interscholastic softball coaching experience preferred. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill and/or ability required. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
Education and/or Experience: High school certification and three years head coaching experience preferred. Prior successful experience working in a school setting or coaching student athletes strongly preferred.
Accurate Reporting: Educators shall accurately report information required by the local board of education or governing board, state education agency, federal agency or state or federal law.
Financial Management: Educators shall ensure all school funds and accounts are managed in a responsible and transparent manner. Educators shall ensure school property, public funds or fees paid by students or the community are not used for personal gain. Educators shall not make decisions based upon gifts, gratuities, favors or the socioeconomic status of parents, family members, community members or businesses.
Interpersonal Skills: Works well with others from diverse backgrounds. Focuses on solving conflict; maintaining confidentiality; listening to others without interrupting; keeping emotions under control; remaining open to others’ ideas and contributing to building a positive team spirit. Demonstrated ability to successfully coach, lead and/or motivate adolescent students.
Culture and Team building: Ability to work in alignment with the district’s strategic plan. Conducts oneself in a manner consistent with the district’s core values, mission and vision. Demonstrates ability to build relationships with athletes, parents and school community. Demonstrated ability and experience in creating and maintaining a positive and inclusive team environment
Language Skills: Ability to communicate fluently verbally and in writing in English. Ability to effectively present information and respond effectively to questions in one-on-one, small group situations to students and other school staff. Ability to verbally respond to common inquiries from students. Ability to read and interpret documents such as safety rules, operating instructions, procedure manuals and regulations. Ability to write general reports and correspondence.
Mathematical Skills: Ability to add, subtract, multiply and divide in all units of measure, using whole numbers, common fractions and decimals. Ability to compute rate, ratio and percent.
Reasoning Ability: Ability to define problems, collect data, establish facts and draw valid conclusions. Demonstrated ability and experience in executing coaching decisions and player selection in a fair, equitable and consistent manner
Ability to interpret an extensive variety of instructions in varying forms. Ability to problem solve and deal with a variety of concrete variables in situations where only limited standardization exists.
Computer Skills: General knowledge of computer usage and ability to use, e-mail, internet software and word processing software. Ability to type accurately and proficiently.
Other Skills and Abilities: Demonstrated knowledge of child growth and development at each level of instruction and of the social, emotional, physical and cognitive development of adolescent students. Demonstrated ability to participate in physically demanding athletic activities. Possesses knowledge of effective behavior management methods. Ability to exercise good judgment and work in a dynamic environment.
Certificates, Licenses, Registrations: Must hold or be willing to obtain the following certifications: Fundamentals of Coaching, Concussion Training, First Aid or Sports Injury Prevention Training, CPR/AED, Sudden Cardiac Arrest (Lindsay’s Law), Ohio Department of Education Pupil Activity Permit.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Essential duties of this position include the following. Other duties may be assigned. 1. Follows and maintains knowledge of all District policies and procedures. 2. Instructs and teaches skill sets and techniques necessary for individual and team achievement in softball 3. Establishes a fair and objective manner for executing player selection and effectively communicates with students regarding selection decisions for team rosters 4. Demonstrates a willingness to meet with the parent(s) or guardian(s) of any student who is a member or trying out for the team 5. Demonstrates the ability and/or experience to create and maintain an inclusive team culture 6. Plans and sets-up activities, practices, and games in conjunction with the athletic director 7. Ensures a certified coach is present at all softball practices and games 8. Develops appropriate training programs and practice schedules 9. Ensures that proper cleaning, storage, and maintenance of all athletic equipment and uniforms and updated inventories are adhered to 10. Arranges game transportation for athletic participants in conjunction with department of student life 11. Travels with student athletes for all events or assigns a School District approved designee to travel with all other levels, on the team bus both to and from games 12. Adheres to all financial policies of the district in regard to the collection and disbursement of money, expenses, and receipts 13. Makes recommendations regarding the purchase of uniforms, equipment and supplies 14. Works directly with the Athletic Director in preparing softball practice and game schedules 15. Maintains necessary records and completes required paperwork in a specified time and manner 16. Ensures that proper form(s) (insurance, attendance, medical) are obtained and current 17. Ensures that all student athletes practicing or playing have been cleared through the Athletic Director’s office 18. Enforces discipline policies and emphasizes sportsmanship and healthy lifestyles. Supervises students in locker rooms at home and away games and ensures appropriate behavior 19. Checks and secures all office, storage room, outside doors, locker rooms and all lights after the last player leaves after games and practices (Head Coach may delegate this responsibility to an Assistant Coach) 20. Ensures that appropriate rules and regulations regarding the conduct and eligibility of athletic activities and athletes are explained and followed 21. Maintains a safe environment and facilities for student athletes at all times 22. Ensures that medical and safety requirements are adhered to Coordinates with the Press and reports game scores 23. Follows OHSAA rules and regulations 24. Follows Ohio Capital Conference rules and regulations 25. Provides guidance for the youth and middle school girls softball programs. 26. Assists in the selection and training of Assistant Coaches 27. Works with Athletic Training when reporting injuries 28. Reports and secures approval from the district for all adults associated with their sport 29. Submits athlete rosters to the Athletic Director three weeks before the first game, any changes to student information on the roster, inventories (copy to Office Secretary as well), final season statistics and alphabetical list of awards immediately following the season (list includes the number of awards earned and the class of the athlete 30. Consults with the Athletic Director regarding any off-season training programs 31. Assigns duties to all assistant coaches under his/her jurisdiction, including pre-season practice sessions 32. Interacts thoughtfully and courteously with students, staff, parents, fellow coaches, and officials and resolves conflict in a professional manner 33. Appropriately maintains and secures confidential records and inquiries 34. Professionally represents the school and the District in interactions with student, parents, community, staff and the media 35. Maintains appropriate certifications and training hours as required 36. Attends work regularly and is punctual
MARGINAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Marginal duties of this position include the following. Other duties may be assigned. 1. Attends inservice training and staff meetings as needed. 2. Sanitizes and cleans equipment. 3. Inspects facilities and athletic courts for health and safety concerns. 4. Chaperones/supervises athletic events, as needed
SUPERVISORY RESPONSIBILITIES All school employees have some responsibility for supervising standards and assisting in maintaining a safe environment
PHYSICAL DEMANDS The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly required to communicate. The employee is frequently required to move; sit; use technology. The employee must have the ability to teach proper techniques and skills needed for athletic participation.
Work Environment

The Girls Golf Assistant at Broken Arrow Public Sch. is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Girls Golf Assistant are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Broken Arrow Public Sch. use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Girls Golf Assistant recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Girls Golf Assistant collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Girls Golf Assistant maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Broken Arrow Public Sch.. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

The Assistant Coach - High School Boys Lacrosse position at Jenks Public Schools provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Assistant Coach - High School Boys Lacrosse prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. Jenks Public Schools Job Description
Position: Assistant Coach – Jenks Wrestling Club
Reports to: Director of Community Education and Assistant Director – Athletics, Community Education
Supervises: None
Qualifications: 1. High School diploma or GED required. 2. Previous success in an assigned coaching position is preferred but not required. 3. Extensive knowledge, skills and ability in the strategy and technology of the sport. 4. Experience interacting with student athletes, parents, and assistant coaches through deliberate positive interactions. 5. Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics at Ida B. Wells HS is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Ida B. Wells HS reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Head Boys Tennis Coach - Ida B. Wells HS - 25/26 SY - District Athletics may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Ida B. Wells HS. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics role at Franklin HS emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Franklin HS, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Franklin HS at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Head Girls Soccer Coach - Franklin HS - 26/27 SY - District Athletics must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Franklin HS.

The District believes that extra-curricular activities are an integral part of school life. Job.JobDescription: Description Bend-La Pine Schools is committed to the principle of equity. Equity supersedes the notion of equality, where all are treated the same. Pursuing equity requires the removal of barriers and the promotion of inclusive practices so that all students fully benefit. The principle of equity will inform all BLS policies, regulations, programs, operations, practices, and resource allocations. Studies have shown that some individuals (women and people of color, for example) are less likely to apply for jobs unless they believe they meet every single qualification in a job description. Our goal is to find the best candidate for the position, and we acknowledge that that candidate may be an individual from a less traditional background. We encourage you to apply, even if you don't believe you meet every one of our qualifications described. If you are unsure whether you meet the qualifications of a position, or how this would be determined, please feel free to contact Human Resources to discuss your application. Classification Title: Boys' Volleyball Coach Reports To: Athletic Director Pay: Extra Duty Salary Schedule, Range Classification Definition: This classification encompasses assignments that support co-curricular and extracurricular programming across athletics, student activities, and enrichment opportunities. These roles provide students with structured opportunities that extend beyond the core curriculum and may occur outside the traditional classroom setting, and promote skill-building, personal development, and increased belonging. Assignments under this classification are made on a year-to-year basis and may be seasonal or year long, depending on program needs.

Job.JobTitle: 1.0 FTE Assistant Softball Coach – La Pine High School – Regular
Job.JobDescription:
The 1.0 FTE Assistant Softball Coach – La Pine High School – Regular role at La Pine High School is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the 1.0 FTE Assistant Softball Coach – La Pine High School – Regular is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at La Pine High School are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The 1.0 FTE Assistant Softball Coach – La Pine High School – Regular listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the 1.0 FTE Assistant Softball Coach – La Pine High School – Regular encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. The Middle School - Track Assistant Coach position at Reading School District provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Middle School - Track Assistant Coach prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Reading School District, the Middle School - Track Assistant Coach works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Middle School - Track Assistant Coach encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Middle School - Track Assistant Coach at Reading School District is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Track and Field (3 positions available)
Job.JobDescription:
At DASD, we are committed to sharing values of diversity and inclusion in order to achieve and sustain excellence in education. As a diverse district, we continually seek ways to strengthen our educational environment. We believe that we can best promote excellence by recruiting and retaining a diverse group of staff who bring various backgrounds and perspectives. Our ability to create and maintain a climate of respect is critical to attaining the best teaching and learning environment.
At the Downingtown Area School District we value our employees. We seek to hire new staff who: Communicate openly to build relationships and trust Partner with team members to see the TEAM succeed Demonstrate a growth mindset and seek ongoing opportunities for growth Embrace and support a safe and inclusive environment Eagerly and enthusiastically support student learning Strive to be kind and reflective Focus on the solution and put people first Lead by example!
If you want to be part of our "Downingtown Proud" team - please apply! Help us with our mission to educate all students to meet the rigorous challenges of a global society.
Job Summary: Duties may include supporting the head coach, ensuring that equipment and facilities are maintained, and performing administrative duties. Assistant coaches may also schedule and supervise practice sessions, maintain training equipment, and organize team events, all while building a positive team environment.
Qualifications: To successfully perform this position, a person must be able to perform each primary duty satisfactorily. The qualification requirements listed below represent minimum levels of educational achievement, training, skills and/or ability necessary.
High school diploma or equivalent Track and field experience required Previous coaching experience preferred Effective interpersonal and communication skills Must successfully complete and maintain compliance with all federal and state background and criminal recordcheck requirements Click here for more information about required clearances Candidate must adhere to all local, state, federal, and school code requirements for employment
Job.Experience: Track and field experience required, Previous coaching experience preferred

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - PMS - HEAD Coach - Boys Lacrosse maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at PEIRCE MIDDLE SCHOOL. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track

The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track at STETSON MIDDLE SCH is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At STETSON MIDDLE SCH, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Co-Ed Track at STETSON MIDDLE SCH allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball position at STETSON MIDDLE SCH is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At STETSON MIDDLE SCH, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - ASST. Coach - Softball role at STETSON MIDDLE SCH is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball at STETSON MIDDLE SCH is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at STETSON MIDDLE SCH reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the 2025-2026 (Spring) Supplemental Contract - STETSON MS - HEAD Coach - Softball may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at STETSON MIDDLE SCH. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobDescription:
Under direction of the school principal at Classical High School and the Athletic Director/or appropriate supervisor/ Administrator, Individuals will be available three hours each day during the entire season.
This position is contingent upon the following: Preference will be given to internal/school based staff and co-op school staff. Successful recruitment of team members and ability to field a team for practice and game conditions. Proper physical conditioning related to the sport during practice sessions. Successful completion of the interscholastic season You must complete the new hire compliance training prior to your first day of employment Bilingual Preferred Selected candidate will be required to pass a pre-employment criminal history background check. Selected candidates cannot begin work until passing their background check.
Salary Rate Range: 10% of Teacher Salary Scale
EDUCATION REQUIREMENTS: RIDE Requirements: Must be certified in accordance with the new RIIL Coaching Permit Requirements
Qualifications: BA in education or related field preferred but not required. Have current CPR/First Aid Certification in possession (required) Principles of Coaching. Psychology of Coaching. Athletic Training (Prevention and care of athletic injuries). Bio-mechanics (Analysis and understanding of human movement). Previous playing and coaching experience preferred. Dedication to the service of youth and ability to gain and hold the respect of team members.
DESCRIPTION OF DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Teach fundamentals and skills. Organize practice sessions. Keep records and report results to local media. Provide Principal and Athletic Director an outline of a general practice session. Conduct coaches meetings and assign coaches responsibilities. Provide for care and prevention of injuries. Conform to all rules established by the Principal's Committee on Athletics and perform duties in accordance with the Providence School Department Athletic Handbook. Teach rules and regulations of the sport. Display good sportsmanship at all times. Responsible for the issuing, maintaining, and collecting of equipment. Prepare team budget. Recruitment of players and advancement of the sport.
Position Type: Part-Time Salary: $4,834 to $9,112 Per Year
Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required
Job.Location: Classical High School - Providence, Rhode Island

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys' Volleyball Coach position at Cranston High School West is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people.
