Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach at Manheim Township is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Manheim Township reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Varsity Assistant Baseball Coach may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Manheim Township. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

The Coach - Girls Volleyball, Assistant Coach (Fall) position at Wissahickon High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Coach - Girls Volleyball, Assistant Coach (Fall) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Wissahickon High School, the Coach - Girls Volleyball, Assistant Coach (Fall) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Coach - Girls Volleyball, Assistant Coach (Fall) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Coach - Girls Volleyball, Assistant Coach (Fall) at Wissahickon High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions)
Job.JobDescription:
The Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions) at Avon Grove Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Avon Grove Middle School, the Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Avon Grove Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Middle School Girls Softball Coach (2 positions) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Head Junior High Field Hockey Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Position Title: Head Junior High Field Hockey Coach
Job Goal: This position involves coaching, mentoring, and guiding student-athletes in individual skill development and team strategies. The coach will also be responsible for fostering a positive and inclusive team culture, ensuring the safety and well-being of players, and always representing the school professionally.
Qualifications: Minimum of 3 years coaching experience (head coaching preferred) Proven coaching techniques and in-depth knowledge, including rules, strategies, and district and PIAA regulations Strong communication, organizational, and leadership skills Ability to foster effective relationships with administrators, staff, students, parents, and governing bodies Commitment to academic and personal development of student-athletes Ability to assess and develop players and coaches Professional demeanor and motivational leadership Effective communicator with strong human relations skills Commitment to equity, diversity, and inclusion Willingness to uphold school policies and work flexible hours, including evenings and weekends Availability to meet with students and parents outside of instructional hours A head coach/assistant coach must be dedicated to organizing and maintaining a structured off-season workout program that supports the ongoing development of their athletes. This involves planning and supervising conditioning, skill-building, and strength training sessions to ensure progress throughout the year and team readiness.
Application Process: All required clearances must comply with the Pennsylvania Department of Education’s mandated criteria for hire. Questions may be directed to the Athletics Department at 717-270-6770 or asinico@lebanon.k12.pa.us All required clearances must comply with the Pennsylvania Department of Education’s mandated criteria for hire.
Application Deadline: The position will remain open until the appropriate candidate is selected.

Job.JobDescription: NORTH HILLS SCHOOL DISTRICT AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER As required by North Hills Education Association Contract Article XVII, Section B, the following coaching vacancy is posted for the 2025-2026 school year: POSITION: The North Hills School District is seeking a Varsity Head Track and Field Coach QUALIFICATIONS: Demonstrated successful experience coaching at the high school or collegiate level (head coaching experience preferred). Comprehensive knowledge of track and field, meet planning, and program organization. Commitment to fostering academic success, sportsmanship, leadership, and character in student-athletes. Excellent communication and organizational skills. Ability to build positive relationships with students, staff, parents, and community members. All required clearances in accordance with Pennsylvania state law. RESPONSIBILITIES: Lead and oversee all aspects of the varsity track and field program, including staff selection, and meet preparation. Coordinate off-season strength and conditioning programs. Promote the varsity track and field program within the school and community. Ensure compliance with all district, WPIAL, and PIAA policies and regulations. Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High position at Berkeley County is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High at Berkeley County sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Berkeley County, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the 2025-2026 Temporary Employee - Head Boys B-Team Baseball Coach - Stratford High position at Berkeley County is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.
Job.Experience: 3 years preferred coaching experience

Job.JobDescription: Position Title: Coach, Assistant Department: Athletics Reports To: Head Coach SUMMARY: To help each participating student achieve a high level of skill, an appreciation for the values of discipline and sportsmanship, and an increased level of self-esteem. ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Assists the head coach in any assigned duties related to football in addition to coaching the Varsity team. Assumes responsibility for checking all practice areas each day and removes hazardous objects from the practice area. Helps develop a positive public relations program in the school and the community. Assists the head coach in developing a well-organized practice schedule that maximizes practice time and develops student-athlete skill in football. Assists the head coach in working with athletics director to develop a competitive yearly game schedule. Assists the head coach in completing and submitting all required AHSAA and local system reports in a timely manner. Assists the head coach in developing and implementing an effective scouting program. Attends all staff meetings, clinics, and other professional development activities. Assists the head coach in implementing an effective injury prevention and care program. Assists the head coach in developing and implementing an effective strength and conditioning program. Assists the head coach in ensuring that all football activities are in compliance with AHSAA and local system policies and procedures. Assists the head coach in maintaining a current inventory of all football equipment, supplies and materials. Assists the head coach in developing and implementing an effective off-season program. Assists the head coach in working with the athletics director to ensure that all football facilities are properly maintained. Assists the head coach in working with the athletics director to develop and implement an effective fund-raising program. Performs other duties as assigned by the head coach and/or athletics director. QUALIFICATIONS: High School Diploma or GED required. Experience as a football coach at the high school or college level preferred. Must possess effective coaching techniques and skills. Must possess knowledge of the rules, regulations, strategies, and techniques of football. Must possess the ability to establish and maintain effective working relationships with school administrators, parents, and students. Must be able to communicate effectively both orally and in writing. Must be able to work independently and with others. Must be able to work evenings and weekends. Must be able to travel as required. PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. While performing the duties of this job, the employee is frequently required to stand; walk; sit; use hands to finger, handle, or feel; reach with hands and arms; climb or balance; stoop, kneel, crouch, or crawl; talk or hear; and taste or smell. The employee must frequently lift and/or move up to 50 pounds. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close vision, distance vision, color vision, peripheral vision, depth perception, and ability to adjust focus. WORK ENVIRONMENT: The work environment characteristics described here are representative of those an employee encounters while performing the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions. While performing the duties of this job, the employee is regularly exposed to outside weather conditions. The employee is occasionally exposed to wet and/or humid conditions; moving mechanical parts; high, precarious places; fumes or airborne particles; toxic or caustic chemicals; extreme cold; extreme heat; risk of electrical shock; explosives; risk of radiation; and vibration. The noise level in the work environment is usually moderate. Term of Employment: Seasonal Athletic Supplements Pay Scale Evaluation: Performance of this job will be evaluated annually according to Board Policy. The information contained in this job description is for compliance with the American with Disabilities Act (A.D.A.) and is not an exhaustive list of the duties performed for this position. Additional duties are performed by the individuals currently holding this position and additional duties may be assigned. Updated 2019

Job.JobTitle: Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School at Nation Ford High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Nation Ford High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Boys Volleyball JV Assistant Coach - High School at Nation Ford High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.
Job.Experience: Preferred

Job.JobDescription:
The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School at Springfield Middle School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Springfield Middle School, the Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Springfield Middle School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Girls' Soccer Coach - Middle School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.Experience: Preferred

The Soccer - Varsity Assistant Coach (Girls) -2026 demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 position at Dutch Fork High School provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Dutch Fork High School, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Volleyball - Varsity Head Coach - 2026 at Dutch Fork High School is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

The Assistant Athletic Director role at Chapin High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Athletic Director coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Chapin High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Athletic Director reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Chapin High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Athletic Director may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Athletic Director monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Athletic Director must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Chapin High School.

Job.JobTitle: Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys
Job.JobDescription:
The Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys at Dutch Fork High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Dutch Fork High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Dutch Fork High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Dutch Fork High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Golf - Junior Varsity Head Coach - Boys role at Dutch Fork High School.

Reports To: School Athletic Director and/or School Administration Job Summary: Rock Hill Schools is seeking a dedicated and knowledgeable Athletic Coach to lead, motivate, and develop athletes to reach their highest potential in both skill and character. The Athletic Coach will plan and implement practice sessions, guide athletes in training and competition, promote teamwork and sportsmanship, and ensure the health and safety of all participants. Key Responsibilities: Develop and execute effective training programs and practice plans. Instruct athletes in the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport. Evaluate athlete performance and provide constructive feedback. Foster a positive team culture that emphasizes discipline, effort, integrity, and mutual respect. Ensure adherence to all rules and regulations set by the school, league, or governing body. Monitor the physical and mental condition of athletes, including injury prevention and first response. Coordinate with assistant coaches, athletic trainers, and other staff. Communicate regularly with athletes, parents, and administration. Attend all practices, games, meetings, and required events. Maintain equipment and inventory related to the specific sport. Serve as a role model and mentor to student-athletes. Qualifications: Proven coaching experience in [specific sport, e.g., basketball, soccer, track, etc.]. Knowledge of sport-specific techniques, rules, and strategies. Excellent leadership, motivational, and organizational skills. Strong interpersonal and communication abilities. Satisfactory background report Preferred: Experience coaching at the [high school/collegiate/professional] level. Relevant coaching certification (e.g., NFHS, USA Coaching, etc.) Start Date: Determined by Human Resources. PRE-ONBOARDING REQUIREMENTS: As a condition of employment and prior to onboarding, the district will conduct a criminal history background check. The recommended candidate will be required to provide personal information necessary to complete the background check such as date of birth, gender, and race to remain in compliance with applicable laws and regulations. DISCLAIMER: The District reserves the right to modify job postings and/or job descriptions at any time to meet organizational needs. EEOC STATEMENT: Rock Hill Schools provides equal employment opportunities to all employees and applicants for employment and prohibits discrimination and harassment of any type without regard to race, color, religion, age, sex, national origin, disability status, genetics, protected veteran status, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or any other characteristic protected by federal, state or local laws. Job Requirements: Citizenship, residency or work visa required

Title: Athletic Coach Spring Golf Work Location: Gallup High School Contract Length: Spring Sport Minimum Salary: $6,000.00 Maximum Salary: $6,000.00 *Internal applicants MUST attach a signed Permission to Coach Form to application* ATHLETIC COACHING LICENSE, 7-12 High School Diploma or Equivalency AND Must hold or have the ability to obtain an Athletic Coaching License (https://webnew.ped.state.nm.us/bureaus/licensure/how-to-apply/athletic-coach-7-12/) from the New Mexico Public Education Department as well as completing the Fundamentals of Coaching online exam offered through the New Mexico Activities Association. (www.nmact.org) QUALIFICATIONS: 1. Has the ability to organize and supervise a total sports program. 2. Has previous successful coaching experience in assigned sport. (Major sports) 3. The head coach must have substantial knowledge of the technical aspects of the sport and, at the same time, must continue to examine new theories and procedures pertinent to the field. 4. The head coach must serve as an appropriate role model for student athletes through his/her instructions and actions. REPORTS TO: The athletic director, who provides overall objectives and final evaluation in conjunction with the high school principals. WORK ENVIRONMENT: On-Site attendance is mandatory for this position. SUPERVISES: In several instances, the head coach must advise, coordinate and support a staff of high school assistant coaches and middle school coaches in conjunction with the athletic director and respective principal. JOB GOAL: To instruct athletes in the fundamental skills, strategy and physical training necessary for them to realize a degree of individual and team success. At the same time, the coach must instruct and demonstrate behaviors that lead to socially acceptable character development, self-discipline, self-confidence, and pride of accomplishment in the student athletes. To upgrade his/her knowledge and skills through coaching clinics, observations, consultation, etc. Work with students interested in sports, provide necessary practice support and advice for a team to be successful against opposing teams in a sports season. Teach and enforce rules and regulations. Involves work on evenings and weekends.

Job.JobDescription: BEGINNING DATE: 25/26 Season SALARY: $3,300 APPLICATION: IN-DISTRICT: Letter of interest through School Spring - Applicant Tracking. OUT-OF-DISTRICT: Complete application through the School Spring - Applicant Tracking APPLICATION DEADLINE: UNTIL FILLED QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have a coaching license or a coaching application with results from the NMAA to apply for their coaching license and a complete application on file. JOB SUMMARY: To prepare athletes for competition. Participation opportunities are offered at the Varsity, Junior Varsity, 'C' Team, 9th-grade, 8th-grade, and 7th-grade levels of competition for many of the sponsored sports. ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Teaching sports techniques, playing rules, strategies, and playing tactics. Conditioning athletes appropriately for activities requiring endurance, strength, and agility. Supervising and conducting practices and contests safely; supervising locker rooms and buses. Teaching sportsmanship, cooperation, work ethic, and responsibility to one's team. Monitoring athletes' school attendance, grades, and personal conduct. Job Requirements Citizenship, residency or work visa required Contact Information Nelson Diaz , Assistant Principal Athletic Department Phone: 575-546-8841 Email: nelson.diaz@demingps.org

BEGINNING DATE: 25/26 Season
SALARY: $3,300
APPLICATION: IN-DISTRICT: Letter of interest through School Spring - Applicant Tracking. OUT-OF-DISTRICT: Complete application through the School Spring - Applicant Tracking APPLICATION DEADLINE: UNTIL FILLED
QUALIFICATIONS: Applicants must have a coaching license or a coaching application with results from the NMAA to apply for their coaching license and a complete application on file.
JOB SUMMARY: To prepare athletes for competition. Participation opportunities are offered at the Varsity, Junior Varsity, 'C' Team, 9th-grade, 8th-grade, and 7th-grade levels of competition for many of the sponsored sports.
ESSENTIAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Teaching sports techniques, playing rules, strategies, and playing tactics. Conditioning athletes appropriately for activities requiring endurance, strength, and agility. Supervising and conducting practices and contests safely; supervising locker rooms and buses. Teaching sportsmanship, cooperation, work ethic, and responsibility to one's team. Monitoring athletes' school attendance, grades, and personal conduct. Responding to player injuries with approved first aid techniques. Managing uniforms, equipment, and school facilities in a responsible manner. If Major sports course is offered- Expected to actively participate in offseason program development and implementation, including strength and conditioning, skill development, and team activities. Involvement with the school's major sport athletic class during the academic day is required.
SPECIAL CONDITIONS: Vacancies for coaching positions are developed at each school and forwarded to the Associate Superintendent of Human Resources for posting in schools. Candidates for coaching positions are screened and interviewed by the high school athletic director and/or principal. To apply for a coaching job, candidates submit a letter of interest to the office of Human Resources. The athletic director will review all candidate backgrounds and recommend candidates to be interviewed.
SALARY: Coaching salaries vary depending on the coaching assignment and the level of competition (Freshman, Sophomore, JV, or Varsity). Applicants should list related playing or coaching experiences and any training completed. In addition, candidates should list the sports they feel most comfortable teaching/coaching. (List sports in order of capability.) For further information, interested persons should call the Deming Public Schools Director of Activities and Athletics at 575-546-8126.
Revised January 2026

The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Head Coach (STIPEND) at Douglas High School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Head Coach (STIPEND) manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Douglas High School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Head Coach (STIPEND) demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Head Coach (STIPEND) follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Head Coach (STIPEND) at Douglas High School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) at Douglas High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Douglas High School, the BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Douglas High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The BASEBALL BOYS JV - Assistant Coach (STIPEND) follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) role at Jerome High School emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Jerome High School, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Jerome High School at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Assistant Track Coach (Sprints and Hurdles) must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Jerome High School.

This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Grizell Middle School, the Head Boys Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach at Grizell Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Grizell Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Grizell Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Grizell Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Boys Lacrosse Coach role at Grizell Middle School.

The Head Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Head Softball Coach is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Grizell Middle School, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Head Softball Coach encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Head Softball Coach also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Head Softball Coach role at Grizell Middle School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Assistant Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Assistant Softball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Assistant Softball Coach at Grizell Middle School sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Grizell Middle School, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Assistant Softball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Assistant Softball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Assistant Softball Coach position at Grizell Middle School is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.CompanyDescription: Westerville City School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Middle School Football Head Coach - 8th Grade
Job.JobDescription:
POSITION SUMMARY: Coach middle school grade level team(s), supervise a grade level middle school football program and coordinate the middle school program between grade levels and with high school program.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTION:
Organize and coach all practice sessions. Coach all scheduled games. Organize and coordinate practice schedules of all football teams at that grade level. Assure that students are supervised continuously and require students to behave appropriately. Supervise the distribution, collection and inventory of all equipment. Prepare written inventory of all equipment prior to start of season and at conclusion of season. Inspect all equipment and be responsible for seeing that equipment is maintained and safe for student use. Prepare equipment for reconditioning. Coordinate and supervise fitting of students for equipment. Prepare a written practice schedule and distribute weekly to students/parents, Middle School Athletic Director and Middle School Administrators. Collect, maintain, and distribute to appropriate personnel all emergency medical forms and medical information about students. Conduct parent meeting prior to start of season. Prepare budget for MMS football program that is submitted to MMS Athletic Director. Prepare written budget requests for MMS athletic director that will be forwarded to Quarterback Club. Comply with the academic eligibility requirements of the Ohio High School Athletic Association, the Marysville School District and the Marysville Middle School. Inform students and their parents weekly of any eligibility problems or if student is ineligible Organize and conduct award program. Prepare and organize all necessary records and forms. Complete paperwork as directed by MMS athletic director and/or building administrators. Serve as a role model for student athletes in the promotion and practice of sportsmanship, ethical principles and responsible behavior. Communicate effectively and work cooperatively with students, staff, parents and community members. Prepare written announcements regarding practices, games, etc. for MMS announcements. Prepare written summaries and information concerning MMS football games, etc. for local newspaper. Inspect MMS game and practice facilities and report to MMS Athletic Director any concerns, etc. concerning facilities. Uphold the rules and guidelines of the OHSAA, Board of Education, Athletic Department and the MMS Student Handbook. Coordinate the MMS Football program with MHS Football program. Communicate with MHS Head Varsity Coach and MHS Football assistants about skills to be taught, etc. at this level. Maintain the locker room facilities. Organize and supervise the physical conditioning program prior to start of season. Provide written information to students and MMS Athletic Director about such programs prior to end of previous school year. Communicate any violations of policies or improper conduct of coaches to MMS Athletic Director in a prompt and timely manner. Supervise other MMS Football coaches and provide written input to MMS Athletic Director for the purpose of evaluating these coaches. Communicate regularly and frequently with the other MMS Head Football Coach in order to coordinate the total MMS Football program.
OTHER DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
Other duties may be assigned by the Middle School Athletic Director, Middle School Principal or High School Head Football Coach.
QUALIFICATIONS:
Pupil Activity Supervisor Validation. Ohio teaching certificate/license preferred. CPR certification with mandatory annual review.
REQUIRED KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES:
Ability to teach and evaluate the skills of the sport. Football experience and/or knowledge of football. Ability to effectively supervise high school athletes and work with them in a positive manner. Ability to work cooperatively with adults. Ability to meet the practice and contest time requirements specified by the Athletic Director or Principal.
EQUIPMENT OPERATED:
Blocking and tackling sleds. Audiovisual equipment.
WORKING CONDITIONS:
Potential exposure to blood or other bodily fluids. Regular exposure to hazardous athletic equipment. Close proximity to people running. Potential exposure to unruly people. Exposure to dust, pollen and inclement weather conditions. NOTE: The above lists may not be ranked in order of importance.
CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT:
Length of Employment: Contract runs concurrent with school year; Football season will run approximately August through November Salary: Supplemental pay, step one or appropriate experience step level Fringe Benefits: None
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
Please submit a letter of interest and resume to the online application. Please do not send materials through U.S. mail or by e-mail, all documents should be uploaded to your application.
If your qualifications meet our needs we will contact you for further information and a possible interview.
Job.SalaryRange: Supplemental pay, step one or appropriate experience step level

Job.JobDescription:
POSITION SUMMARY: Coach the seventh and eighth grade track team.
ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS: Organize the practice sessions. Coach the practice sessions and the scheduled meets. Supervise students continuously while on duty, and require students to behave appropriately. Assist the High School coaches with the development of the entire 7-12 program. Distribute, collect and inventory the equipment. Assist with record keeping and the presentation of awards to the athletes. Communicate effectively and work cooperatively with students, staff, parents and community members. Serve as a role model for student athletes in the promotion and practice of sportsmanship, ethical principles and responsible behavior. Enforce the academic eligibility requirements of the Ohio High School Athletic Association, the Marysville School District and the Marysville Middle School. Observe all safety and health regulations of the school district. Follow the Athletic Director’s rules and the applicable rules in the middle school student handbook. Maintain the locker room facilities. OTHER DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES: Other duties may be assigned by the Middle School Athletic Director, the Middle School Principal or the High School Head Track Coach. QUALIFICATIONS: Pupil Activity Supervisor Validation. Ohio teaching certificate/license preferred. CPR certification with mandatory annual review.

Job.JobDescription:
The HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach position at Chuck Jaco is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach at Chuck Jaco sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Chuck Jaco, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the HS Assistant Girls Volleyball Coach position at Chuck Jaco is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

The Berea City School District believes that education empowers, inspires, and encourages lifelong learners to thrive in a changing global society. We are committed to attracting and supporting talented staff who contribute to the success of our students and schools. We strive to create and maintain a positive and supportive working and learning environment for all.
Educational and employment opportunities are offered without regard to race, color, national origin, sex, or handicap. Note: Qualified applicants who are disabled and require special assistance to respond to this employment announcement should contact the Berea City School District Personnel Office at 216-898-8300.

The MS Baseball Coach at New Albany Middle School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the MS Baseball Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At New Albany Middle School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The MS Baseball Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The MS Baseball Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at New Albany Middle School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent New Albany Middle School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the MS Baseball Coach reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the MS Baseball Coach role at New Albany Middle School.

The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) at OF HIGH SCHOOL is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at OF HIGH SCHOOL use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Weight Room Supervisor - Spring (Internal Only) maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at OF HIGH SCHOOL. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.Location: OF HIGH SCHOOL - Olmsted Falls, Ohio

Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) role at OF HIGH SCHOOL is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at OF HIGH SCHOOL are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At OF HIGH SCHOOL, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Assistant Girls Lacrosse Coach (Internal Only) at OF HIGH SCHOOL, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.
